TES is a global green energy company focused on developing giga-scale projects to produce hydrogen-based e-fuels, such as e-NG (electric natural gas made from green hydrogen and CO2). Based in Europe and operating worldwide, TES uses renewable power combined with climate-neutral CO2 to create e-NG, a drop-in fuel that can replace fossil natural gas exactly like biomethane. This scalable and cost-effective approach aims to provide reliable and affordable green energy globally by building on existing infrastructure and processes. TES seeks to accelerate the adoption of green molecules across various sectors by making them easy to transport and consumeto deliver on real zero targets and win the climate race. We welcome the public consultation of the upcoming strategic foresight report, and in particular its focus on resilience, inter alia of the energy system. To reach this goal, a variety of increasingly renewable sources of energy will be required moving forward. Beside ensuring that a variety of technologies can be supported, it will also be key to guarantee that the EU can continue to rely on safe and secure import of renewable energy sources, while quickly scaling up its own internal production capacity and internal market for renewable energy sources. To this end, a focus on the below would be recommended in our view: 1. Remaining committed to our existing EU targets while defining ambitious milestones towards 2035, 2040, 2045, 2050 and beyond. There is no way back. It is crucial to reconcile competitiveness with decarbonisation targets and ensure that they are both achievable and sustainable. To this end, the EU should continue pushing for high renewable and low-carbon targets across Member States and build on new and existing initiatives (eg the COP, IEA Clean Energy Ministerial) while putting forward policy tools such as renewable gas blending mandates successfully featured in Canada, Japan or France, to mention a few; 2. Ensuring adequate financing, simple funding rules, and financing tools, are put in place to achieve our objectives will be fundamental. An assessment of the available funding at EU and Member States level, along with a forecast to be included in the upcoming MFF negotiations should be incorporated to ensure that funding channels are sustainable and realistic o The proposal of an industrial decarbonisation bank to channel funding (whether ETS-based or other) into the most cost-effective decarbonisation option for different end-user sector should be supported and quickly implemented as low-hanging fruits to reducing our emissions; other schemes should be simplified and/or integrated to simplify the landscape o Renewable-focused funding should be clearly earmarked maintained, to ensure that our long-term objective remains clear and locks-in our energy system into the most sustainable pathway in terms of resources; o Technology neutrality must rule, with an objective lifecycle assessment methodology to gauge on the emission reduction benefits 3. Implementation of existing EU legislation, targets and rules is paramount to ensuring the resilience of the EU and a level-playing field across Member States. The example of the Renewable Energy Directive (2023/2413) and its ability to unlock business cases when properly implemented across the EU along with its targets and facilitating internal market tools (such as the Union Database) is a case in point. TES believes that by (1) ensuring regulatory certainty and stability through accelerated and full implementation of EU legislation and targets across Member States (2) earmarking sufficient financing for decarbonisation objectives that can ensure security of supply and resilience and making it simple to access and (3) ensuring that clear and ambitious targets and milestones are set-out towards 2035, 2040, 2045, 2050 and beyond, the EU will be able to decisively reconcile increased competitiveness and resilience.

feedback: Any vision for a resilient EU must be grounded in the harsh realities ahead: - Demographic challenges: By 2040, the EUs workforce is projected to shrink by nearly 2 million workers annually, while the ratio of working to retired people will decline from approximately 3:1 to 2:1 (Draghi Report, 2024); - Geopolitical shifts: By 2040, Europe will not only lose its demographic dividend (when economic growth is supported by a rising population, but the era of the peace dividend will be long gone (von der Leyen, 2025); - Increased defense spending: The Readiness 2030 initiative, aimed at strengthening European defense, is expected to reshape budgets, with military expenditures rising to 57% of GDP (European NATO/EDU scenarios, EPRS The Future European Security Architecture, 2025); - Economic and environmental costs: The green premium initiative reflects the financial burden associated with the green energy transition and climate mitigation efforts (ESPAS Global Trends to 2040). With these developments in mind, it is reasonable to envision a future where revenues from trade have declined, but Europe heavily taxes both businesses and individuals. These tax revenues are used to finance a substantial EU resilience fund that supports social equality across the EU. Where the EU admits it or not, this fund has led to an internal societal debate on which socio-economic paradigm is the most effective (Joint Research Centre Reference Foresight Scenarios 2040). In my view, any paradigm we adopt must begin with redefining the relationship between the citizen (taxpayer) and the state (administration). The EU can no longer afford a system where Big Data is used solely to combat presumed tax avoidance rather than to understand and incentivize compliant taxpayer behavior. A new level-playing society should uphold transparency not only for taxpayers but also for administrations. The principle of no taxation without representation must be more than a slogan. What needs to be done? - Reduce the tax compliance burden; - Implement real and meaningful simplifications; - Introduce regulatory sandboxes to test innovative tax policies; - Increase accountability in tax administration; - Use the power of AI to empower the taxpayers, to understand their taxing rights and obligations! A truly open society acknowledges that, whether we like it or not, if corporate power continues to expand, large corporations may need to be given a greater voice than they have today within international organisations that establish global standards and co-ordinate responses to global challenges such as climate change, national security and technological safety (OECD, Strategic Foresight Toolkit, 2025). In short, readiness for 2040 (and beyond) must involve a shift toward a dialogue between unbiased algorithms those of tax administrations and those of taxpayers as well as a true partnership between governments and taxpayers, united by common long-term goals.

Translate Foresight into Policy Action Establish mechanisms to integrate foresight insights into real-world decision-making. feedback: The foundation of modern economies relies on the consumption of finite resources, especially fossil fuels, to fuel growth, which ultimately leads to environmental degradation, resource depletion, and inequalities in wealth distribution. The concept of endless economic growth on a planet with limited resources is inherently unsustainable - the paradox of infinite growth within a finite world. The necessary transition to a new economic model needs to ensure that prosperity is shared more equitably among all people. This brief note (prepared by the SPES project Sustainability Performances, Evidence and Scenarios to inform the Strategic Foresight Report) wants to highlight the main long-term EU challenges and propose solutions with the intent of enhancing the economic system resilience, meanwhile promoting Sustainable Human Development to expand sustainable and inclusive wellbeing for all. Considering the most recent relevant literature, we attempt to unify the thoughts towards a shared consensus that can finally lead to the ultimate beyond-GDP transition. This requires conscious governance and collective action by all societal actors, where solutions must be built around sustainability and resilience, and definitively not by wealth or power.

feedback: The insurance industry works every day to protect people and businesses. UNESPA is the Spanish Association of Insurers and is member of Insurance Europe. The association was founded in 1977 and represents approximately 200 insurers that together cover almost all the insurance business in Spain. These undertakings have a turnover of 62,000 million euros every year, or in other words, almost 5.1% of Spanish gross domestic product (GDP). They protect assets and people, which are valued at more than 10 times the GDP of Spain. UNESPA highly appreciates the focus of the 2025 Strategic Foresight Report on resilience. The Commission efforts to strengthen consistency and synergies between all EU policies aiming to promote long-term resilience will certainly contribute to the success in moving towards a safer and more prosperous future for all Europeans. The insurance industry is willing to work closely and constructively with the Commission, supporting initiatives that strengthen the resilience of Europe's economy and society. That includes initiatives to enhance preparedness and close existing protection gaps in a number of areas, such as climate risks or cyber risks, among other threats and hazards, as highlighted in the Niinisto report. To enhance preparedness, policymakers should carry out initiatives to raise awareness among citizens and businesses about risks facing them and their properties and about existing protection gaps. Policymakers should also implement initiatives to increase the insurability of risks. That would include risk prevention and risk protection awareness policies for both the public and private sectors. Furthermore, appropriate regulatory frameworks for prevention should be developed and appropriate incentives should be established for companies to invest in these prevention and protection measures, including financial support to SMEs by public aid through European funds. Insurance coverage provides financial protection and helps swift recovery from damage, but insurers cannot provide cover without data. Therefore, policymakers should ensure insurers can access and make use of data. This includes allowing customers to consent to sharing data from their vehicles, apps, and personal devices. Data is vital across all areas of insurance for pricing, risk analysis, risk mitigation and prevention, innovation, and fraud detection and prevention. In order to close the protection gap in the EU, public-private partnerships should be promoted, in particular in the area of increasingly frequent and severe extraordinary climate risks. The EU faces significant investment requirements to address climate change, enhance security, attain self-sufficiency in energy, food, and technology, and finance growth. To meet these demands, it is essential to close the pension savings gap and to increase retail investments including through insurance savings and retirement products. Closing the pension savings gap and providing financial security for individuals in a context of ageing populations, requires the implementation of measures such as: pension savings gap calculation tools to inform all workers annually about their estimated future pension; incentives to savings in supplementary occupational (second pillar) and individual (third pillar) pension schemes, the development of automatic enrolment employment systems; or the development of a pension dashboard, as proposed by the European Insurance and Occupational Pensions Authority (EIOPA) to monitor the evolution of the three pillars of pension systems in the Member States. To increase the retail participation in the financial markets, policymakers should simplify and modernise the investment process for Europeans, providing clear and streamlined customer information and avoiding disproportionate burden for financial providers without significant added value for customers. Finally, policymakers should continue efforts to strengthen the dialogue with all key stakeholders.

Summary of our response: As recognised in the Call to Evidence for the 2025 Strategic Foresight Report, resilience needs to be delivered in a sustainable, fair and democratic manner with a join up across policy priorities. The 2023 Foresight Report was right to identify that the sustainability transition is built on a triple promise: a healthy planet and thriving environment; economic growth that is decoupled from resource use and environmental degradation; and an assurance that no person or place will be left behind. That report made strong links between environmental sustainability and economic resilience but mostly related this to the transition to a net zero economy with some reference to the damage caused by pollution. The 2025 Foresight report needs to make a stronger link to the EUs ambition for a zero pollution economy and specifically the need to reduce the production, use and import of harmful chemicals. CHEM Trust welcomes the opportunity to explain the importance of including chemical regulation in the policy actions needed to strengthen resilience in the EU. The EU is facing multiple crises of climate change, chemical pollution and biodiversity loss that are interconnected and are impacting on citizens health, the ecosystems that humans depend upon and the economy. Increasing pollution of our environment and our bodies with toxic chemicals are key challenges that must be addressed in any strategy to ensure a resilient and desirable future. It is surprising therefore that the last Foresight Report (2023) did not include specific reference to chemical pollution despite containing a strong recognition of the need for environmental sustainability and wellbeing to be at the heart of resilience. Our answers to the specific questions set out in the Call for Evidence together with our supporting evidence and our policy recommendations are in the attached document.

feedback: The Centre for Future Generations welcomes putting resilience at the core of the 2025 Foresight Report. In support of the European Commission's efforts to enhance coherence and synergies between policies relevant to strengthening long-term resilience, our response has combined our expertise with issues the Commission is looking to tackle, covering broader EU resilience questions and specific emerging technology policy topics encompassing advanced AI, biotechnology, climate interventions, neurotechnology, foresight, and technology governance. The landscape of challenges for long-term EUs resilience and strengths EU can build on sit in the nexus of geopolitical context and governance mechanisms, reflected in impact on economy and competitiveness. For 2040, we envision resilience built on a democratically strong, politically stable, and socially just EU, with the capacity to mitigate emerging risks, successfully competing globally, and with a regulatory and policy-making capacity underpinned by strategic foresight. We see emerging technologies, across AI, climate, neurotech, biotech integrated into public systems across healthcare, education and economy at large, to address societal needs and challenges, with equal access for all citizens. In 2040, the EU remains at the forefront of climate adaptation and mitigation, having successfully decarbonized its economy, established climate-resilient infrastructure, and pioneered nature-based solutions to protect ecosystems and communities. Its agriculture, urban planning, and economic systems are fully adapted to a changing climate, ensuring long-term stability and prosperity across the continent. We recommend that intergenerational fairness be placed at the heart of a resilient society, especially in terms of fostering intergenerational dialogue and building a profound understanding of the impact todays policy decisions will have on future generations. Adequate investment in innovation, paired with regulation, alongside development of trustworthy AI systems, are essential for the vision of the EU in 2040. Following the recommendations of the Draghi report, the increase of public and private R&D investment is a critical pathway to resilience in 2040. CFGs institutional blueprint report, Building CERN for AI (https://cfg.eu/building-cern-for-ai/), address the creation of a pan-European AI research institution that could transform EUs technological landscape, serving as both a driver for innovation and a safeguard for responsible AI development. In biotechnology, a wide area of advanced technologies with various applications, there are three policy pillars where policy action taken today can drive long-term resilience: 1) securing biomanufacturing supply chains and capacity through biofoundries, 2) strengthening bio-based autonomy via defence and strategic industries, and 3) biosecurity and safe innovation. Across mental health and neurotech, critical actions foreseen include: 1) embedding mental health in all policies, 2) revisiting the digitalisation agenda with respect to digital literacy, data protection and a balanced approach to digital engagement, and 3) balanced approach to the risks and opportunities of neurotechnologies. Additionally, a strategic, integrated approach to address climate change (including as a security risk) is needed, by leveraging existing foresight capabilities and closing governance and research gaps. Advancing strategic foresight is the core lever to achieve long-term resilience. Rigorous empirical approaches can help policymakers better compare uncertainties and identify scenarios where early interventions can make the biggest difference. We are currently working on foresight methods innovation that would in this sense complement widely used futures literacy to help additionally rigorously assess long-term risks and uncertainties, and prioritise concrete actions.

feedback: Water resilience is one of todays biggest challenges. Climate change, causing water stress, associated with increasing industrial demand for water, are forcing us to rethink how we treat water, both from a quantity and quality point of view. To meet these current and future challenges, it is crucial to deliver on a strong and ambitious European Water Resilience Strategy. This urgency affects everyone, at all levels and across all sectors. It is therefore essential that the cross-cutting nature of water is considered through strengthened governance and the development of stronger synergies between EU policies. As governance at the basin level can present challenges for regions and Member States, it is crucial to reinforce transboundary cooperation at the operational, tactical, and strategic levels, with mutual and harmonised processes and obligations. The European Commission must as well ensure that obligations related to water availability and quality are fully enforced in the EU, by better controlling the implementation of existing water policies. Furthermore, the EU must prioritise circular solutions, such as the reuse of treated wastewater, encourage aquifer recharge to maintain groundwater levels, combat leaks in water networks, and encourage the digitalization of water management processes. Finally, the EU should push Member States to rethink the price value of water to promote a more rationale use of the resource. The selling price of water is currently too low to enable water management operators to effectively fulfil their mission: ensuring a sufficient supply of quality water both today and in the future. The undervaluation of water hinders the investment opportunities needed for the deployment of necessary infrastructures and the development of innovative water-smart solutions.

feedback: The European Union faces significant challenges to long-term resilience while possessing substantial strengths upon which to build. Environmental pressures, including climate change, biodiversity loss, and resource scarcity, represent major threats, while outdated governance structures struggle to handle contemporary demands. Technological dependencies, particularly in digital services and critical minerals, add complexity to the challenge. Despite these challenges, the EU maintains powerful foundations: a strong institutional framework, leadership in environmental policy through the European Green Deal, extensive infrastructure, growing research capabilities, and high social cohesion. By 2040, the EU envisions itself as a global leader characterized by net-zero emissions, digital sovereignty, robust social cohesion, adaptive governance, and strong environmental stewardship. Achieving this vision requires immediate action. Critical policy initiatives include integrating climate risks into security frameworks, developing renewable energy sovereignty, creating circular economy systems, implementing digital sovereignty measures, and establishing multilateral climate security approaches. To ensure intergenerational fairness, the EU must implement just transition frameworks, develop green job opportunities, create universal civic service programs, invest in lifelong learning platforms, and establish sustainable pension systems. Key synergies exist between green and digital transitions, social and economic policies, and internal and external security measures. However, tensions must be managed between economic growth and environmental protection, national sovereignty and EU integration, and short-term costs versus long-term benefits. To enhance strategic foresight, the Commission should implement regular horizon scanning exercises, strengthen member state communication networks, systematically integrate foresight scenarios into policy design, develop adaptive governance models, and enhance stakeholder participation in foresight processes. Success depends on leveraging existing strengths while actively addressing current challenges through enhanced strategic foresight and careful management of synergies across policy domains. The transformation to a resilient EU by 2040 requires fundamental changes in governance approaches. Moving beyond traditional top-down leadership, the EU needs to adopt more adaptive models based on orchestration, facilitation, experimentation, co-creation, and collaboration. This transformation necessitates differentiated integration strategies that respect Member States' unique contexts while fostering collective progress. The regulatory system must evolve to incorporate open innovation ecosystems, experimental arenas, and outcome-based legislation rather than rigid rules. Success in this volatile context requires a new, reinvigorated approach that leverages qualities and competencies such as openness, inclusiveness, agility, strategic sensitivity, and the ability to adapt quickly to changing environments. Ultimately, building EU resilience by 2040 also demands a cultural shift in governance and policymaking. The EU must move beyond its current risk-averse approach while maintaining its commitment to democratic values and social welfare. This requires developing greater responsibility and engagement among citizens, potentially including sacrifices for the common good. Strategic autonomy, particularly regarding Big Tech, digital services, and IT industry independence, emerges as a crucial focus. Europe should drive, shape, and prepare for transformations related to AI. Success will depend on the ability to balance competing interests, unlock ecosystem development, and maintain prosperity for citizens in an increasingly turbulent world. The EU's future resilience will be shaped by its ability to transform environmental and social challenges into opportunities for progress, leadership and partnership development.

feedback: We imagine a future in 2040 where EU industry holds defensible positions in many major value chains, supported by a highly skilled workforce, a high-quality research, development and innovation (RD&I) ecosystem, and integrated European innovation investment and policy. Polarization in society is reduced, not only by accepting grassroots input into policymaking but also by installing policies aimed at improving quality of life and reducing inequalities. Achieving this requires overcoming our current challenges (such as over-reliance on non-EU states for energy and materials, slow governance, lack of focus in innovation funding) and leveraging our key strengths (such as our strong R&I ecosystem, regulatory leadership, a large single market). Key policy lines include building up a high-tech industry through sustained support for RD&I. A long-term vision, combined with constant monitoring of progress and the courage to discontinue underperforming initiatives will foster confidence and unlock investment. However, the interplay between various priorities presents both synergies and tensions. For instance, there is tension between protecting industry and supporting free trade; conversely growing wellbeing and restoring natural capital are mutually supportive. Fully understanding these dynamics requires considering higher-order impacts, delayed feedback loops, and the inherent unpredictability of human behaviour. The complexity of these interrelationships necessitates a comprehensive approach to strategic foresight. Strategic foresight could be enhanced by combining foresight with System Dynamics to capture the complex feedback loops within the strategic foresight work. This can be achieved through several approaches. One approach is to develop future scenarios and then create a System Dynamics model from scratch representing the scenarios, effectively modelling the system of the future. Another approach is to create a model of the current system while developing future scenarios in parallel and then exploring how the system behaves in each scenario, thus modelling the future of the system. A third approach is to create a both a model of the current system and the ideal future, and then backcasting from the future into the current system, modelling how the current system enables or prevents change. TNO has piloted an approach to combine System Dynamics and foresight, using Arctic melting as a use case. This pilot provides valuable insights and a collaborative methodology that can be adapted and applied to other areas. The integration of System Dynamics and foresight offers a robust framework for understanding and navigating the complexities of strategic planning and policymaking in the EU.

The University of Bergen (UiB) appreciates the opportunity to give input in connection with the preparation of the Strategic Foresight report for 2025 and welcomes its timely focus on resilience. UiB wishes to emphasize the importance of long-term perspectives to ensure European resilience. We also encourage a broad understanding of the term, taking into account that a complex set of factors contribute to societal resilience, and consequently that knowledge from a broad range of fields is necessary for efficient knowledge-based policy-making for resilience. In demanding times with many challenges requiring immediate investment and effort, it is vital to remember that investment in research and research-based education and innovation upholds the necessary foundations for long-term resilience, and for the resilience of democratic societies in particular. European democracies and values as we know them today have developed in critical dialogue with European history and tradition over centuries. An inclusive public sphere open for critical discussion informed by knowledge, not only of current issues, but also of languages, history, and the rich multitude of cultural perspectives present in our societies, is a central part of our democratic interaction. To uphold this, we need free independent media, quality education and strong research environments within the whole range of disciplines, including social sciences, humanities, law and art (SSHA-disciplines). In general, research, education and innovation secure the knowledge and competences needed for efficient policies for resilience and competitiveness now and in the coming years, and lay the basis for discovering the knowledge and developing the competences we need in the longer term that we do not yet envisage. Research and education of the highest quality is a clear strength of European countries, built through long-term investments in universities and other research institutions. To be able to meet the various challenges we face globally and in Europe, it is vital to continue strengthening the European Research Area and thereby the European research and innovation ecosystem. This requires promoting and protecting academic freedom, improving career opportunities for younger researchers and providing funding opportunities for researchers and innovators along the whole continuum from fundamental research to innovation for the market or societal implementation. To attain this, it is crucial that the EU continues its commitment to research and innovation (R&I) through a stand-alone framework programme for R&I with a strong and ring-fenced budget in the next Multiannual Financial Framework. UiB wishes to point to the research areas listed below as central for the resilience of European societies, and as areas where European collaboration provides clear added value. We recommend that they be prioritized in the last years of the current framework programme for R&I, Horizon Europe, and in the next, 10th, framework programme (FP10): Children and youth Climate Democracy and sustainable, just and inclusive societies Digitilization and Artificial Intelligence Efficient energy systems and energy systems management Health Oceans and the blue economy Sustainable area management These interconnected areas require both basic and interdisciplinary research, with SSHA-disciplines integrated into all themes. Sufficient investment in infrastructure, including data-sharing systems and data stewardship roles, is essential for maximizing European R&I potential. To be able to mobilize excellent R&I environments in all sectors to participate in the programme, it will be of great importance to secure long-term stability with regard to the budget as well as rules and conditions. For further details on these research areas and further recommendations on FP10, we refer to UiBs recommendations concerning thematic priorities in FP10 and UiBs Position paper on FP10 (attached).

feedback: A main challenge for EU policy is demographic resilience. More specifically, it is the way that demographic change transforms the basis on which pension systems, the labour market, or networks of care were built. When a crisis or shock hits, these systems come under pressure, as we have seen during the Covid-pandemic. Europe must be able to withstand further crises of comparable dimensions in the future. For this, European policies need to ensure enough skilled workers enter in its critical jobs (health, mobility, administration, etc.), as well as an availability of enough carers (family caregivers, neighborhood help, volunteers, etc.). The following are findings from the EU-funded FutuRes research project and Policy Lab. A demographically resilient EU in 2040 would be one in which: accessibility to the labour market is much improved for younger people, older people, women and groups with disadvantages the financial disadvantages of family caregiving and childrearing are removed: people who take time off or work part time in order to care no longer pay for this with lower pensions local communities act as pillars of care and cohesion: instead of leaving the task of caring for older people and children on the shoulders of fewer and fewer blood-relatives, the local level is empowered to improve neighborhood and community support. institutions regularly engage in latest foresight methods What needs to be done today to strengthen resilience in the EU by 2040: 1. Make labour markets resilient: o Explore migration and automation as options, but do not overly rely on them o Focus on increasing the labour market participation rate o Make critical jobs more attractive For more detail on these recommendations see: https://population-europe.eu/research/policy-insights/skills-shortage-eu-ways-towards-labour-market-resilience 2. feedback: The concept of control points is crucial when considering resilience. Control points are high-value, unique business activities (or networks of activities) that create strong dependencies towards public and/or private actors. Building up control points provides both a measure of security and a negotiation position, mitigating against future (economic or geopolitical) shocks. Although the concept of control points is gaining traction, descriptions of control points are remaining mostly anecdotal. TNO Vector is working on a systematic study of control points, exploring how control points can be measured, aiming to understand success factors of establishing control points and proposing metrics to measure progress towards securing control points. The first part of this study is publicly available (https://vector.tno.nl/artikelen/grip-control-points-gerichter-innoveren/). Here we describe control points from three perspectives: the individual company, network and geopolitical perspectives, with initial criteria for the control point in each. Although this study takes the Dutch perspective, the insights are translatable to a European level. Follow-up studies are in train to identify current and potential control points, both within the Netherlands and internationally. These studies are expected to provide actionable insights towards current or future control points; and towards mitigating or circumventing control points of others. Insights from these studies can be shared in confidence to inform the Strategic Foresight Report.

The 2025 Strategic Foresight Report should highlight the need for systematic EU policy action in the field of youth resilience, as a key pillar of sustainability, social cohesion, and the future competitiveness of the Union. Young generations are called upon to navigate multiple, simultaneous crises climate change, technological transformation, geopolitical uncertainties, and demographic challenges. Notably, 63% of the jobs that will exist by 2030 have not yet been created, while 35% of the skills currently in demand will have completely changed by 2027 (source: World Economic Forum Future of Jobs Report, 2023). This rapid transformation of the labour market intensifies uncertainty about the future of young people and requires an immediate and coordinated policy response. Therefore, it is proposed that a comprehensive European Strategy for the "Resilience of Young Generations" be introduced, based on three key pillars: Education for resilience and critical thinking Upgrading educational systems to include skills related to psychological resilience, adaptability, uncertainty management, and critical handling of disinformation. Social and economic stability Adopting policies that ensure young people have access to decent work, affordable housing, and quality healthcare services, supporting their autonomy and enabling them to build stable personal and professional futures. Participation and empowerment Strengthening the institutional role of youth in decision-making processes, through mechanisms for participation and by fostering youth leadership initiatives at both national and European levels. A youth resilience strategy is not simply an investment in the future; it is a necessary condition for a sustainable European transition, for addressing social inequalities, and for maintaining trust in European values and institutions.

My project arises from the need to move beyond the concept of a mere European community and toward the creation of a genuine European population, one bound not only by shared institutions but also by a deep and authentic sense of belonging. This transformation can only be achieved through education, shared values, and widespread cultural awareness. A decisive step in this direction would be the introduction of European Culture as a mandatory subject in schools across all member states. This educational journey, spanning from primary to secondary education, would provide young people with the opportunity to explore the history, principles, and extraordinary cultural diversity that define Europe. Instead of erasing national identities, this initiative would enrich them and transform the European Union from a political abstraction into a lived reality. To make this vision concrete, European Culture should become an integral part of school curricula, taking the Italian school system as a reference, since it is the one I am most familiar with, with one or two hours per week at each educational level. In primary school, the approach should be narrative and playful, sparking curiosity through stories, games, and activities that introduce children to different european cultures and traditions. In lower secondary school, the focus should shift to the history of European integration, the functions of its institutions, and the key challenges the EU has faced over time. Finally, in upper secondary school, students should engage with major global issues impacting the continent, participate in decision making simulations, and visit European institutions to gain firsthand experience of how the Union operates. To reinforce this awareness, we should also symbolically celebrate our common journey by establishing official non working days on important historical dates such as 26 March, the anniversary of the Schengen Agreement, and 7 February, marking the signing of the Maastricht Treaty. Initially, these days would spark curiosity, especially among those unfamiliar with Europe's most significant historical milestones. The chance to pause from work and celebrate a shared occasion would naturally lead people to question its meaning. Over time, these dates would become deeply embedded in collective memory, transforming from mere holidays into moments of reflection and unity. They would stand as reminders of Europe's journey, ensuring that future generations not only acknowledge these milestones but truly understand and cherish their significance. We have before us an extraordinary opportunity to transform Europe from an abstract concept into a real, lived experience. To build a new generation that no longer questions whether they are European but simply knows they are. Today we begin building a Europe of Europeans.

feedback: Europe is facing a competitiveness crisis and also a growing water quantity crisis. To address this, all measures in the Water Resilience Strategy should prioritize the Water Efficiency First Principle. Below are ECOLABs recommendations for the EU Water Resilience Strategy No EU Competitiveness without properly managing Water in industry: As industry uses more than 50% of freshwater in Europe it has a key role to play in addressing the rapidly growing gap between water supply and demand in the EU. This must be a key component of a truly water-resilient society. The water dimension should be woven into all EU policies, especially on climate and industry as: We cannot talk about decarbonization without talking about water We cannot talk about competitiveness for our industries without talking about water We cannot talk about AI without talking about water The good news is that: It is possible for industry to reduce water use, energy use and carbon emissions at the same time by leveraging the water-energy-productivity nexus With todays existing solutions, we can reduce up to 40% of companies' water utilization while making them more efficient and profitable. This is especially critical for sectors like chemicals, semiconductors, data centers, food & beverage, and renewable hydrogen The EU Water Resilience Strategy (WRS) offers a unique opportunity to drive the adoption of sustainable water management and innovation in the water space With the right mechanisms and a holistic approach to water and energy, we can accelerate and scale existing technologies and innovations while strengthening the competitiveness of key EU sectors. Regional Measures: Water is local and measures that are effective in water-stressed areas do not have the same impact in wetter regions. The WRS should mandate the development of National Water Plans to: Foster water sobriety for all actors with clearly defined water withdrawal reduction targets Optimize resource availability via water conservation plans for all sectors Preserve access to water with targets for water reuse Circularity: Water reuse in Europe is 2.5%, while other regions have achieved significantly higher rates, e.g. 90% in Israel and 10% in California and Saudi Arabia. One major barrier to water reuse is restrictive regulation limiting the use of recycled water in certain sectors. France has removed these barriers, resulting in environmental benefits without impacting human health The WRS must harmonize local legislation to incentivize the highest possible amount of safe water reuse The WRS should be closely linked to the Clean Industrial Deal, the Circular Economy Act and the Vision for Agriculture Measurement: To determine sustainable water use, a precise quantitative assessment of water supply and demand at specific locations is essential. This process is vital as the inability to determine sustainable water use is a significant obstacle to progress in water management and stewardship, hindering investments needed to secure long-term business viability for operations and supply chains. Precise measurement is therefore a strategic imperative, recognizing the critical role water plays in enabling growth, profitability, and competitiveness The WRS must introduce an EU-wide water accounting system with enhanced data interoperability Funding: Achieving a truly water-resilient Europe will require both public and private funding for public water agencies and infrastructure The WRS should create Water-Transition Funds, either as a separate funding vehicle or under the next Multiannual Financial Framework to invest in water Water Efficiency First Principle: This should align closely with the EEF Principle: 1. It is anchored in legislation through a suitable Directive or Regulation 2. Water demand is reduced across all sectors without placing the burden on consumers 3. EU countries are obligated to consider water efficiency solutions in planning, policy, and investment

The European Union stands at a crossroads where resilience must transcend crisis response and become a foundation for redefining prosperity, democracy, and quality of life in a multipolar world. This report embraces Radical Optimism and Lucid Optimism as guiding principles. Radical Optimism is not naive hopeit is a deliberate act of reimagining possibility, asserting that even within constraints, alternative futures can be designed. Lucid Optimism, as described by Joël de Rosnay, acknowledges the weight of reality while choosing to act towards beauty, agency, and meaningful transformation. Resilience is therefore not just about enduranceit is about reinvention. Whether in geopolitics, economy, urbanism, or digital governance, the EU must craft a future that is desirable rather than merely survivable. This requires bold choices, from cultivating cultural sovereignty and cognitive autonomy to reshaping economic models towards vitality rather than extraction. By identifying levers of desirable resilience, this report aims to empower policymakers, designers, and change-makers with a framework for foresight-driven actionone that does not merely anticipate but actively designs the future. feedback: We welcome the focus on long-term resilience in the 2025 Strategic Foresight Report. As the world faces numerous crises, Europe faces both the challenge and the opportunity to rethink its approach to building resilient economic and societal systems. Resilience and intergenerational fairness are deeply connected as resilience is not just bouncing back and overcoming immediate challenges but also bouncing forward to ensure future generations inherit stronger, more adaptable systems. Designing policies for intergenerational fairness, or intergenerational thinking, ensures that todays policy decisions are grounded in a comprehensive understanding of current and future trends. To fully use intergenerational thinking in promoting a resilient EU, we recommend further embedding strategic foresight in policymaking, utilising sustainable and inclusive wellbeing metrics, strengthening citizen participation processes, and ensuring horizontal coordination. 1. Strategic foresight: Streamline the use of existing and innovative strategic foresight practices of the Commission into the policy cycle to support long-term decision-making. These practices can feed into the annual work plan, budget, and the work of DGs, with support from the JRC. In addition, we invite the Commission to build the muscle, i.e. develop a habit of using foresight and strengthen the necessary skills through practice to be able to use these resources more efficiently, making them less resource-intensive over time. The Commissions Strategic Foresight Network can continue to give guidance and support capacity building across various DGs. The Network could cooperate more with the Better Regulation Network to share insights and identify synergies. The networks could also convene to build capacity among members on how to use strategic foresight to improve regulatory quality. 2. Sustainable and inclusive wellbeing (SIW) metrics: SIW metrics are centred on measuring progress across three dimensions: a. Ensuring future wellbeing (sustainability); encompassing biophysical and social conditions for future wellbeing. b. Limiting wellbeing inequalities for current and future generations (inclusion); gauging the distribution of wellbeing determinants and opportunities across spatial scales and social groups. c. Ensuring current wellbeing (wellbeing); determinants such as health, education, air quality, employment, social relationships, income, housing, security, and environmental health. A holistic set of indicators can enable the EU to assess the long-term sustainability of its strategic decisions by integrating different factors. It is abruptly triggered, either by an exceptional natural or human-caused event such as a climate tipping point, a volcanic eruption or a nuclear attack, or by a more gradual systemic crisis. Focusing on policy proposals, here is a selection from section 4 on policy from the Resilient foods for preventing global famine paper: 1) Development of a Food Security Strategy that includes these shocks (vulnerability assessments, quantification and supply of food, water and energy needs, infrastructure needs), 2) Development of plans for fuel management in a GCFF (supply, rationing, and deployment of fuel alternatives like biofuel) 3) Targeted investments (strategic stockpiles of seeds, other agricultural inputs, critical parts for machinery, information infrastructure for dissemination of contingency plans, biorefining capacity) 4) Establishing collaboration agreements with neighboring nations in case of global food crises, and assessment of the local cost-effectiveness of resilient food options, such as crop relocation, redirection of crops used for animal feed or biofuels, and seaweed. The attached food resilience papers highlight climate shocks, supply chain disruptions, and attacks on critical infrastructure as pressing threats. Yet the EU can leverage its robust research institutions and established legal and policy frameworksfor example, the Common Agricultural Policy, the EU Contingency Plan for Food Security and the Critical Entities Resilience Directiveto foster region-specific risk management and knowledge transfer. By integrating adaptive governance, strategic stockpiles, research investments, technology development, and emergency food protocols for GCFF, a more resilient 2040 EU could swiftly address shocks thanks to targeted investments and careful planning. There may be a risk of action-paralysis occurring when dealing with such high impact, high uncertainty events. We believe the opposite should be true. High uncertainty in this context should not deter us from researching solutions and taking cost-effective preparedness measures to increase resilience. A esto se suman diversos desafíos, que, para abordarlos, la prospectiva estratégica busca anticiparse y fortalecer la resiliencia a largo plazo de la UE. Los principales retos en este contexto incluyen el cambio climático, la transición ecológica y digital, la seguridad energética, las crisis geopolíticas, la falta de mano de obra adecuada para los diferentes sectores, en especial la industria, la dependencia de suministros y materias primas del exterior entre otros. Como retos también debemos incluir un impulso del crecimiento de los países miembros, recobrar presencia y peso a nivel internacional y poder garantizar la seguridad de los países europeos en un entorno convulso. Una UE resiliente en 2040 debería ser un Europa cohesionada, fuerte, autosuficiente, industrializada e innovadora, capaz de anticiparse y adaptarse a crisis económicas, sanitarias, climáticas etc. sin comprometer su crecimiento ni competitividad. Algunas de las medidas esenciales que deberían ponerse en marcha para reforzar la resiliencia en la UE son las relativas al apoyo de gran alcance para la reindustrialización de Europa, a garantizar la competitividad del sector industrial, para generar más I+D+i y para avanzar en la Transición Ecológica entre otras. feedback: One of the most significant crises that Europe will have to face in the coming years is the aging of the population in its member states. The European Union's demographic problem is characterized by the gradual aging of its population, as reflected in a series of statistical indicators. One of the most critical factors is the increase in the proportion of elderly people, with 21% of the population aged 65 and over in 2020, compared to 16% in 2001. Even more striking is the rise in the population group aged 80 and over, whose percentage nearly doubled from 3.4% in 2001 to 6% in 2020. At the same time, the proportion of young people under the age of 20 has declined, dropping from 23% in 2001 to 20% in 2020, indicating low birth rates and potential future challenges for economic growth and the sustainability of pension and social security systems. This demographic trend is observed across all member states, with countries such as Italy, Greece, and Germany having the highest proportions of elderly people, while Ireland and Luxembourg have the lowest. The consequences of aging include increased pressure on public finances, the need to restructure labor markets, and reforms in health and welfare policies to ensure intergenerational balance and the long-term sustainability of European societies. Additionally, there should be a reassessment of social benefits, particularly in terms of infrastructure and services for the elderly, in relation to those provided for newborns and children. Of course, this is just one of the many challenges the EU will have to address in the coming years. In order to make better-informed decisions regarding fiscal policy, I believe that Fiscal Foresight should be adopted. A network should be developed where policymakers responsible for shaping fiscal policies both at the EU level and within member states can receive insights from research institutions and universities. Furthermore, citizen participation should be encouraged to help determine the prioritization of different policy areas.

Que en momentos de necesidad no necesitemos traer la comida desde miles de kilómetros. - Fomentar una red de industrias de cercanía que permita obtener bienes fabricados a pocos kilómetros de distancia. Que en caso de pandemia no necesitemos traer mascarillas o respiradores desde China. - Fomentar el autoabastecimiento de energía. Que cada casa tenga sus placas solares, que se aproveche cualquier salto de agua para montar una hidroeléctrica, que haya turbinas eólicas donde corre el viento. En definitiva que la electridad de nuestras casas no dependa del petróleo traído de lejanos países o del gas. - Fomentar la automatización para disminuir los costes de producción y tal vez suprimirlos, permitiendo que todo el mundo tenga acceso gratuitos básicos a los bienes de primera necesidad (alimento, abrigo y alojamiento). El tiempo pasó y el mundo se olvidó de la pandemia. Todo volvía a como estaba antes salvo los precios, que subieron en pandemia pero no bajaron al terminar. La red de dependencia que teníamos para cualquier producto que quisiéramos siguió existiendo. En febrero de 2022 el ejército ruso entró en Ucrania. La dificultad para acceder a los productos que venían de ambos países hizo que los precios volvieran a subir por un conflicto militar de dos países vecinos. El precio de la energía se puso por las nubes y algunos alimentos escasearon en las tiendas. Mucho se habría mitigado si en aquellos dos años se hubiera avanzado en el camino que propuse. Imaginé qué ocurriría si viviera en un país en guerra. Pensé en las penurias que acompañarían a los propios enfrentamientos bélicos: el transporte de mercancías sería muy difícil y caro, las tiendas no podrían vender alimento para todos, las infraestructuras energéticas dañadas no podrían dar electricidad a todos los ciudadanos, reconstruir las viviendas dañadas sería tarea harto difícil sin el transporte apropiado de materiales. Sería muy fácil para el invasor presionarnos destruyendo determinadas infraestructuras o regiones que concentran buena parte de la poca producción local que tenemos. Hasta entonces había enviado varios mensajes más a los principales tomadores de decisión de mi país, así que con el inicio de la invasión rusa envié uno nuevo recordando que mis ideas seguían teniendo validez, y que nos podrían ayudar. feedbackTextUserLanguage: The COVID-19 pandemic in March 2020 led me to reflect on the extensive network of dependencies in which we live. The food we eat every day depends on farmers, livestock farmers and industries generally located hundreds and up to thousands of kilometres from our home. The clothing we wear comes thousands of kilometres away. The energy of our society comes from a wide range of countries. With the pandemic, all flows that depended on people who might become ill were strained: transporters, logistics... Any movement carried out by people could lead to the transmission of the virus, but we needed that movement in order to be able to continue to live as we had previously lived. In April 2020, I shared with my country’s main decision makers (political parties, trade unions, employers’ associations) my views on some changes to be made: — Promoting local production of food and other basic goods. In times of need, we do not need to bring food from thousands of kilometres. — Promote a network of nearby industries that make it possible to obtain goods produced a few kilometres away. In the event of a pandemic, we do not need to bring masks or ventilators from China. — Promoting energy self-supply. That each house has its solar panels, that any water jump is used to assemble a hydroelectric power, with wind turbines running. In short, the electrity of our houses is not dependent on oil brought from distant countries or on gas. — Promote automation to reduce production costs and possibly remove them, allowing everyone to have basic free access to essential goods (food, shelter and shelter). Time spent and the world forgotten the pandemic. Everything came back as before, with the exception of prices, which rose in pandemic but did not fall at the end of the pandemic. The network of dependency we had for any product we wanted continued to exist. In February 2022, the Russian army entered Ukraine. The difficulty in accessing products coming from both countries caused prices to rise again due to a military conflict in two neighbouring countries. The price of energy was set for clouds and some food was scarce in shops. Much would have been mitigated if progress had been made in those two years on the path I proposed. I imagine what would happen if I lived in a country at war. I lack the hardship that would accompany the war clashes themselves: freight transport would be very difficult and expensive, shops would not be able to sell food for all, damaged energy infrastructure would not be able to provide electricity to all citizens, reconstructing damaged homes would be a difficult task without proper transport of materials. It would be very easy for the invader to pressure us by destroying certain infrastructures or regions that concentrate much of the little local production we have. Until then, I had sent several more messages to the main decision makers in my country, so with the start of the Russian invasion I sent a new one recalling that my ideas were still valid and could help us. In this time, I have not received a response (something I imagine) but I have also not seen that the decisions taken in Spain have gone along the way I see as the best, but rather on the contrary: food continues to be produced in distant locations, the local industry is brilliant, the installation of solar panels in houses is not encouraged (they remain expensive and distribution companies take energy without paying citizens) Three years later the changes in the geopolitical board have led me to write a new message. I attach my vision for a resilient EU in 2040 together with the message chains I sent.

Four challenges: 1. "Data as Capital" The forerunners of techno-feudalism GAFA-M are setting the standard for valuing data. Soon, the worth of data and the speed at which it is exchanged will surpass the gold standard and the analog era of capitalism. A failure to recognize the value of (personal) data from knowing someone's favorite beverage to the exact time they enter their car or get on a train, to the production capacity of an industry "competitor" is already generating massive profits for these digital empires. There is little public awareness of the consequences of this data mining, even as these companies construct "The Sims"-like digital twins of pretty much "everything". This is the tip of the iceberg as we fail to assess the impact of Google, Facebook, and TikTok in shaping collective behavior. Today, we see influencers subtly encroaching on personal space; tomorrow, we may witness hyper-targeted advertising that exploits biological signals such as a smartwatch detecting low blood sugar and triggering a perfectly timed beverage advertisement. From predicting to outright shaping the stock market or a political election, with growing room for speculation and other deviations... The collaboration of major corporations like in designing subliminal behavioral manipulation threatens autonomy across all levels (see Yuval Harari "Homo Deus" and other works). Worse, part of this data infrastructure used to extract and exploit information for profit is built with taxpayer money, offering no tangible health/wealth return to society (Citizens are "doubly" taxed for free profit of these companies). 2. Energy Consumption The exponential growth of data/digital comes with a corresponding surge in energy demand. Sustaining this data-driven world requires exponential energy resources, further straining existing infrastructure and accelerating environmental degradation (again, taxpayer money, no return) 3. feedback: Europe in 2040 begins today so what we do today shapes how the future looks and develops. Today Europe is reeling from the US elections and is reacting to sudden geopolitical shifts which has shaken the EU bloc. Foresight now implies that EU must quickly consolidate alliances intra EU in the first instance and then actually succeed in a neighbourhood policy that is result based on matters like technology, trade, climate and conflict resolution. The key sectors are shifting towards AI, renewable energy, health, space technology and social innovation so that our societies must now be prepared for these shifts through R&D and education. . Demographic shifts within Europe are happening at pace often driven by neighbourhood conflict and/or restricted development in these regions. Europe must develop ways to ideas to stabilise these regions including through extending our technology etc to creating prosperity elsewhere. Finally EU citizens in the EU mosaic have a wealth of ideas and experience that can feed into the future solutions so engaging and mobilising the societies will strengthen the alliance from the bottom up. The EU should not simply become a place of big corporations where people work but strong societies where people contribute to common good.

The EU is very fragile due to its internal fragmentation, yet access to the European market is one of the most important geopolitical objectives for both the US, China, and India and any trade block. China has been investing significantly in port infrastructure around the world to avoid being isolated by a trade blockade in the south china sea and areas in the event of a conflict. If a war between China and the US breaks out, the war will be heavily fought over control of trade routes and the ability to deny its use to the adversary. Both India and Europa are completely powerless in this potential conflict. While we do have bases and island chains still around the world from our colonial days, we do not have a fleet to keep trade routes open and to deny blockades. Neither do we have the planes to defend those islands. I would like Europe to consider what its options are if the US starts a war with China and forces Europe into seizing its trade with any China supporter. Likewise, what if China wants to force EU into compliance by shutting down access to entire continents (e.g. deny seafaring through the Suez canal through its bases in Africa). If you look at the map then the US is almost capable of completely denying EU-China trade and also China can cut off significant amount of trade from the EU as they have sufficient bases in Africa to interdict Suez canal traffic and Cape of good horn traffic. They also have bases at the south of India and in Pakistan which means they can interdict India-EU trade. The assumption has always been that we will side with the US and that's still the most likely option but we should really have a choice in this matter when the time comes. Europe should leverage Ukraine's naval drone technology and develop larger ships that can launch them that look like commercial ships (e.g. a container ship with one naval drone per container). This, together with a buildout on historical territories of European countries would enable a European drone fleet to enact sea denial in retaliation. The EU should also create drone jets that can deliver a weapon payload and return to base, sort of like a mini strategic bomber. We can leverage Ukraine's cheap long-range cruise missiles for that. In General, the EU should triple down on investing in Ukraine's defense industry as their innovations are key to the long-term security and trade route security of Europe. Luckily for the EU, large ships such as aircraft carriers and destroyers are no longer relevant and we have an industry in Europe that is the world leader in naval drones. Last, the EU should open its own bases along key chokepoints such as Cape horn (Falklands), Cape of good hope (SA), Suez, Greenland (Northern sea route),... If we don't we (and India) risk to lose freedom of navigation and with that freedom to choose our own destiny and become a pawn of two superpowers. Sadly the international rule-based order is dead, we should secure our vital trade routes with hard power instead. That said, we should absolutely fix our internal fragmentation as well. A hostile China can easily bribe individual leaders/countries to avoid a unified European response. We are in a very short timeframe where our potential adversaries believe that Europe will never unite and can always be managed through exploiting divisions. The Polish Lithuanian commonwealth and its Liberum veto is a cautionary tale. That's why I believe we should give the EU commission the broadest democratic mandate possible and that's only possible if its leader is directly elected across the entire continent. Since proportional electoral colleges don't really work (too much incentive for block-forming) I propose that such a leader would be elected through instant-run off voting. A leader elected in such a way has the broadest possible democratic mandate. This is also needed to stimulate a lot of political debate over what kind of Europe we actually want in the nation states.

Europe's future hinges on its digital resilience, and the 2025 Strategic Foresight Report presents a crucial opportunity to chart a course toward genuine digital sovereignty. The EuroStack Project submits this response, arguing that reliance on non-European tech giants poses a significant threat to the EU's long-term stability and competitiveness. This dependence creates strategic and economic vulnerabilities, jeopardizes data sovereignty under extraterritorial laws like the US FISA and CLOUD Act, and stifles European innovation. A resilient EU in 2040, as envisioned by EuroStack, will be characterized by control over its critical digital infrastructure a "EuroStack" built upon enforceable open standards and Open Source software. This will empower a thriving ecosystem of European businesses, especially SMEs, fueled by secure, interoperable data sharing and a highly skilled workforce. Achieving this vision requires a radical shift: prioritizing Open Source in all publicly funded projects ("Public Money, Public Code"), including public procurement of digital solutions ("Open Source First"), and enforcing interoperability to prevent vendor lock-in. This should extend to the creation of a "European Small Business Act" that favors European SMEs in public procurement. Crucially, building the EuroStack should be a bottom-up effort, leveraging existing, proven European Open Source technologies. Beyond infrastructure, digital resilience demands a holistic approach encompassing digital inclusion for all citizens, ethical AI development, and citizen empowerment through data control. Sustainable financing models, where users directly contract with developers of EuroStack components, will ensure long-term viability. The Commission's strategic foresight can be enhanced by embracing Open Source intelligence, actively engaging with the Open Source community, and prioritizing bottom-up, community-driven initiatives like EuroStack. The synergies between digital sovereignty, economic competitiveness, and cybersecurity are clear. While short-term cost concerns may seem to conflict with long-term sovereignty investments, this is a false economy. The long-term risks of dependence far outweigh any perceived short-term savings. Europe has the strength in its values, a vibrant Open Source community and tech ecosystem, and regulation such as the GDPR. By prioritizing true European solutions, the EU can secure not only its digital future, but its overall resilience and global leadership.

feedback: No existe un intervencionismo económico bueno. El abuso de normas que condicionan las decisiones reduce el mercado, alza los precios y daña el crecimiento, por eso deben ser retiradas una vez se corrijan los excesos. John Locke dejo dicho que los poderes públicos (el Estado) deben intervenir lo menos posible en la economía y en los mercados, pero construir un corpus normativo que garantice el derecho a la propiedad privada y la iniciativa de los particulares como mejor fórmula para lograr el resto de los derechos naturales. Y no precisa demostración que las economías con limitados niveles de intervencionismo experimentan mayores crecimientos, y que aquellas con alta penetración de intervencionismo estatal, tanto en gestión de actividades como en regulación de los mercados, tienen limitaciones al avance de la riqueza ya su reparto. Un vistazo simple a la geografía económica mundial proporciona una escala gráfica con niveles de crecimiento y riqueza directamente proporcional al grado de libertad económica, con los países de mercados abiertos (y democráticos) en un extremo y los estatizados (y no democráticos) en el otro. El problema no está en activar decisiones intervencionistas a través de las normas, sino en no saber retirarlas una vez corregido el defecto del mercado. El Gobierno de España, tanto por la súbita aparición de la última crisis por el Covid como por la propia composición del Ejecutivo tras las elecciones de 2019, ha entrado en una espiral de intervencionismo que amenaza con consolidarse, y que está teniendo efectos perversos en las actividades afectadas, con reducciones importantes del tamaño de los mercados y subidas de los precios, y condicionando decisiones de los particulares que muchas veces van en contra de lo pretendido
feedbackTextUserLanguage: There is no good economic interventionism. The abuse of rules that influence decisions reduces the market, increases prices and damages growth, which is why they must be withdrawn once excesses are corrected. John Locke said that the public authorities (the State) should intervene as little as possible in the economy and markets, but build a body of legislation guaranteeing the right to private property and the initiative of individuals as the best way to achieve the rest of natural rights. There is no need to demonstrate that economies with limited levels of interventionism experience greater growth, and that those with a high penetration of state interventionism, both in terms of activity management and market regulation, have limitations on the advancement of wealth and its distribution. A simple look at the global economic geography provides a graphical scale with levels of growth and wealth directly proportional to the degree of economic freedom, with countries with open (and democratic) markets at one end and the countries statised (and not democratic) at the other. The problem is not to trigger interventionist decisions through the rules, but rather not to know how to withdraw them once the market defect has been corrected. The Spanish Government, both as a result of the sudden outbreak of the latest Covid crisis and the executive composition itself following the 2019 elections, has entered into a spiral of interventionism that threatens to consolidate, which is having perverse effects on the activities affected, with significant reductions in the size of the markets and price increases, and influencing decisions by individuals who often run counter to what was intended.
